awd_titl_txt: Mathematics Education Intensive Residency Project Focusing on Veterans
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, the Mathematics Education Intensive Residency Project Focusing on Veterans will recruit veterans with strong mathematics backgrounds and prepare them to become grade 7-12 grade mathematics teachers. The project will fund twenty scholarships/fellowships over four years. In this project, Mercy College will collaborate with the Yonkers Public School District. The program will implement a clinically rich master's degree program in secondary mathematics education to investigate the nexus between theory and practice, and will benefit Noyce Scholars through the partnership between school practitioners and college faculty. The program will provide recipients with the content and methodology necessary to work effectively in inclusive and traditional mathematics classrooms. Particular emphasis will be given to helping candidates understand the spirit, intent, and content of the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics, and will investigate multiple strategies for implementing successful research-based mathematics education in high-need classrooms. At the conclusion of this 14-month master's degree program, candidates will be eligible for certification and employment. 
 
The project will correlate with current education reform practice to support a cohort model, clinical residency and follow-up induction services as a means for preparing and retaining successful teachers, and will follow the professional development model suggested by data from the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP) and the Center for Teaching Quality. It will guide each cohort through a sequence of activities designed to integrate theory and practice, including research-based courses in teaching, the use of technology in the classroom, differentiated teaching strategies, and implementing the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics.  The program will provide a coherent curriculum and sequenced courses requiring increasing levels of knowledge for application to the clinical residency and emphasize authentic classroom teaching under the mentorship of a well-qualified mathematics teacher and guidance from visiting Mercy College clinical faculty. A year of follow-up support for each cohort will be provided through online seminars, SKYPE and after-school learning workshops. Through multiple sources -- coursework, the internship, certification tests, and the awarding of the degree -- the project will verify candidates' level of competence to teach mathematics curricula in secondary schools, and will evaluate the progress of student achievement in their classes. Data collected from this project will provide an understanding of 1) whether veterans can serve as successful role models for at-risk youngsters by bringing the value-added strengths of maturity and teamwork skills to secondary school teaching and school capacity-building and 2) whether an ongoing learning community will empower a successful transition to civilian life, enable veterans to become effective teachers upon entering the profession, and work productively with diverse populations of secondary school students and educator colleagues.

OUTCOMES STATEMENT by William Farber

The Mathematics Education Intensive Residency Program (MEIRPro) is a Track I, Phase I project designed to improve the quality of teaching and learning of mathematics in high need schools, through the implementation of a clinically rich master’s degree program in secondary mathematics education emphasizing the nexus between theory and practice. The program provided prospective teacher candidates, recruited from the ranks of a diverse group of veterans who have a strong mathematics background, with the content and methodology necessary to work effectively in inclusion and traditional mathematics classrooms in high-need schools. The following Outcomes specify the significant and essential components of the MEIRPro program.

Outcome One:  Successful Completion of a Master of Science Degree in Secondary Mathematics Education

Over seven years, MEIRPro provided for three cohorts consisting of a total of thirteen candidates, recruited from a diverse group of veterans, with strong mathematics backgrounds. All candidates completed the program and received the degree of Master of Science in Secondary Mathematics Education.

Outcome Two: Successful Completion of a Clinical Internship in a High Needs Yonkers Public Secondary School

All candidates completed a 150-day clinical internship in the daily workings of a high needs school community in the Yonkers Public Secondary Schools. The program substituted intensive clinical preparation for traditional student teaching.

Outcome Three: Faculty and teacher-mentor support

Candidates worked under the mentorship of well-qualified mathematics teachers. Mentor teachers served as role models to the student veterans through a pre-teaching experience and helped them with mathematical content, pedagogy, and standards for the diverse school population.

Clinical Faculty: Each candidate received ongoing support from the clinical faculty, who provided onsite visits to candidates and ensured the nexus linking mentor teacher, veteran candidate, and college faculty.

Outcome Four: The Colloquium

A Colloquium facilitated each semester by PI Dr. William Farber was designed to link current research in mathematics education with best practices in the classroom. The Colloquium included guest speakers who are experts in secondary school mathematics.

Outcome Five: Educational Partnerships formed

A strong and ongoing partnership for the improvement of mathematics education was established between Mercy College and the Yonkers Public Schools.  

Outcome Six: Teaching in a high needs’ secondary schools

Of the thirteen veteran candidates who completed the degree program, eight candidates are presently teaching in high needs schools, thus far. Other candidates are completing a certification requirement and/or involved in a job search.

Outcome Seven: Camaraderie formed amongst the veteran students in each cohort

By using the cohort model, a spirit of camaraderie and community developed between the members of each respective cohort. Candidates formed a bond and created a sense of belonging that fostered a collaborative and positive environment of mutual support.

 

Outcome Eight: Support from Leadership Team

 

Dr. William Farber, PI

The Principal Investigator (PI), Dr. William Farber, was responsible for project direction. He collaborated with the Co-PI recruiting candidates, candidate selection, criteria, and training.  Dr. Farber also worked with faculty, supervised clinical faculty, and ensured integration of courses and practice.

Dr. Nagaraj Rao, Co-PI

 

Candidates experienced fieldwork related to the methods course, participating in a project funded by the US Department of Education MSEIP program, and directed by Dr. Nagaraj Rao. Candidates worked individually or in small groups with high school students from culturally diverse and/or minority populations.

 

Professor Rocco Grassi, Project Manager

Rocco Grassi assured all activities and programmatic components were being implemented successfully and were progressing in accordance with the project’s timetable. He maintained student records and assisted with collecting data. Responsibilities also included recruitment efforts, budget, and student advisement.

Professor Christian Esposito, Induction Coordinator

Christian Esposito coordinated the induction year activities for Cohorts One, Two, and Three candidates. His responsibilities included developing a series of online seminars to candidates who have secured a mathematics teaching position, shared lesson plans, provided strategies for classroom management, as well as support for preparing for certification examinations.

Outcome Nine: Support for Candidate Employment

Candidates received training in the writing of resumes, cover letters, and interviewing techniques, which was provided by the Mercy College Office of Career Services. As candidates finished the program, Mercy College faculty supported candidates in finding employment in high-need schools. 

Outcome Ten: The effects and impact of the COVID pandemic on the veteran candidates

It should be noted that a significant number of MEIRPro veteran candidates had COVID 19. Therefore, it is important to note that feedback received from our candidates was not unlike the experiences and challenges facing all teachers, i.e., the strict adherence to CDC COVID Guidelines for Schools, quarantine period, isolation, wearing masks, socially distant classrooms, and mostly virtual teaching. Our Induction Coordinator supported the candidates by sharing online teaching resources. In addition, COVID 19 caused significant disruption at testing centers, and hindered the candidates' ability to complete certification requirements, which includes the tests that candidates need.
